data.author: Anthony Thomas

data.text: The main thing is to stay warm enough. In warm weather/climates it doesn't matter if you get wet. But if where/when you are riding can get down to near freezing point, and pouring in a storm with wind, in a place where there is no quickly reached shelter, it is worth having waterproof trousers of some kind. Cheap lightweight ones will do this emergency type role fine, even if a bit leaky or not at all breathable. They don't have to keep you truly dry (none will in any case), or be super comfy to ride in. You just want them to shed the worst of the water/sleet, and keep the wind off, until you get to shelter or the storm stops.

data.text: The thing that sucks about riding in the rain is if you wear pants they'll stick to your legs. If you wear shorts your socks and shoes will get soaked making it uncfortable at best especially if you have to go through standing water. I usually try to have replacements in a dry bag and look for a laundry mat to throw em in a dryer asap so yourclothes don't rot, anything that's wet from rain except shoes, air dry em otherwise they may separate. Last time I rode in rain it took my shoes about 2 days to dry by air, so a second pair is really necessary. Unless you have a place to pitch a tent for a couple days while your gear dries. data.text: Depending of temperature (cold or warm) I will use rain pants, helmet cover, warmer gloves. Mudguards helps to keep your shoes (feet) less wet. Gore-Tex jacket and pants perform better than regular clothes, but they are very expensive, and you might still get wet depending of how much you sweat. The most important is to stay warm, while you are riding your bike.
